newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine govt. on defensive against graft charges.
newsitem.headline: Argentine govt. on defensive against graft charges.

text.p: Argentina's ruling party rallied to defend the government against charges of corruption in the Cabinet on Thursday while President Carlos Menem moved to demonstrate his determination to stamp out graft.
Former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo's allegations this week that two ministers covered up corruption and manipulated judges put the opposition on the offensive and unsettled financial markets.
A Menem aide said "not one word" about the accusations was discussed in Thursday's Cabinet meeting.

"There was an agenda and this was not important enough for the president," the aide, who requested anonymity, said in an interview. "We cannot let this be an impediment for us to carry on with our policies."

Cavallo, who first denounced "mafias" in public services a year ago, said on Tuesday Interior Minister Carlos Corach tried to remove a judge from investigating a gold-export fraud case and replace him with another who found no evidence of crime.

Cavallo, whom Menem sacked nearly three months ago after a running battle between himself and the Peronist old guard, also said both Corach and Justice Minister Elias Jassan were manipulating judges and state prosecutors.

Argentina's Senate late on Wednesday rejected a motion filed by the opposition Radical Party to question the ministers after the Peronist caucus, which has an absolute Senate majority, turned it down after a long debate.

Menem, who has sought to take the initiative on corruption to boost his poor standings in the polls, on Thursday visited an Air Force hangar where smuggled goods seized at a customs office were displayed to the media.
"Those responsible will go to prison," Menem told reporters. "It was critical to strike a blow as we have to break up these kinds of activities."
Since making his accusations, Cavallo has said he has no documentation or other proof. Menem dismissed them as "lies."
"He says he has no proof," said Jorge Matzkin, leader of the Peronist bloc in the lower house of Congress. "Get serious."
But many Argentines appear to believe Cavallo.
Eighty-one percent of respondents to a poll by pollsters Ricardo Rouvier, published in the daily El Cronista Thursday, said they thought the allegations were probably true.
Early on Thursday, Corach said he would make good on his earlier threat and launch a lawsuit against Cavallo on Friday.
Late on Wednesday, Cavallo gave his support to the president. "I have always supported President Menem. Now that he will face the mafias I will help him even more."
